pages.title: Introduction
pages.content:
Ever put together flat-packed furniture only to find a piece missing? Or leftover screws?

We expect certain things to be put together correctly so they can be effective. The same is true of our written communications. If you want your letter or email to be effective, you need to make sure it has been put together properly.

This topic will explore tips and tricks to ensure your communications have a solid structure and will have the right impact.

pages.title: Plain English and the 5 C's
pages.content:
You may have heard of the rules of Plain English, but do you always follow them? The principles are simple: use everyday words as if you are in conversation with the reader, avoid jargon, keep sentences short and, where possible, always choose active over passive.

These principles are incorporated into a simple formula that can help you to remember how to communicate professionally in your letters. It's called the five Cs.

The 5 Cs are as follows:

  • Courteous
  • Complete
  • Concise
  • Clear
  • Correct

pages.title: Connecting with people
pages.content:
First impressions

You've probably heard the phrase "You never get a second chance to make a first impression", but how long do you think you have to create that first impression with a stranger?

The answer is just 17 seconds!

pages.title: Make connections on the phone
pages.content:
Stages

It helps to think about a phone call as having four separate stages. This helps you to be consistent so all your customers are getting the same great service.

1. Welcome - First impressions count. So give your customer a warm welcome before running through the appropriate security checks.

2. Finding out - listen and ask - This stage is where you need to Listen and Ask in order to gather the information you need.

3. Showing how - educate and explain - Explain to the customer how their query will be resolved and any actions that need to be taken.

4. Closing the call - summarise and confirm - Having done all the hard work, make sure you leave the customer with a good impression by closing the call with the same friendly manner as you started it.

pages.title: What is operational delivery?
pages.content: Operational delivery is a huge professional group made up of everyone who provides services to support or protect citizens in the UK and abroad, or provides support or manages those who, is part of operational delivery. This includes their managers as well. Operational delivery professional roles are grouped by the skills needed to perform them. We call these groups skills families and there are six of them.

pages.title: What the profession aims to achieve
pages.content:
So, we're all working together in operational delivery, and while there are lots of differences in what each of us do on a daily basis, we're all working together towards the same objectives. Let's consider these before going any further.

The aims of the profession are twofold:

  • To deliver the best possible service to the customer.
  • To help employees through recognising and enhancing their skills.

In order to achieve these aims, the profession has the following objectives:

  • For people working in operational delivery to be recognised and valued as professionals.
  • To have transferable skills that are recognised and respected across government and the wider economy.
  • To achieve the same level of status as the more established professions.
